title: Liverpool defensive pair miss training but Mohamed Salah take part ahead of Genk clash
text:

Liverpool defensive pair Trent Alexander-Arnold and Joel Matip both missed the club’s final training session before they flew out to Belgium ahead of Wednsday’s Champions League encounter with Genk.

Both played the full 90 minutes of the weekend draw with Manchester United at Old Trafford.

But both were absent from an open training session at Melwood, offering a way back into the starting lineup for Dejan Lovren and Joe Gomez.

Young full-back Neco Williams was drafted into training with the seniors in Alexander-Arnold's absence; he has made eight appearances for the Under-23 side so far this term and has featured in both UEFA Youth League outings.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

(Image: Getty Images)

Alexander-Arnold was one of seven Reds players named on the 30-man Ballon d’Or shortlist on Monday night.

Another, Mohamed Salah, missed Sunday’s 1-1 draw with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s side due to an ankle injury sustained against Leicester prior to the international break.

But the Egyptian was in training on Tuesday and could feature in Belgium, while Naby Keita is pushing for a place after an impressive cameo at Old Trafford.

Xherdan Shari won't be involved again, as he continues to undergo treatment on his calf issue.

The Swiss is in his homeland for further rehab, and is still yet to feature so far this term.

(Image: Julian Hamilton/Daily Mirror)

Liverpool have three points from their opening two matches in Group E, having beaten Red Bull Salzburg 4-3 last time out.

They enter the game as heavy favourites, with Genk striker Ally Mbwana Samatta - a boyhood Manchester United supporter - labelling it a "dream match".

(Image: Julian Hamilton/Daily Mirror)

(Image: Julian Hamilton/Daily Mirror)

"When I was a kid I used to support a Manchester United but we are not talking about Manchester United right now, we are talking about Liverpool," he admitted.

"We believe Liverpool are a strong team now in the Premier League and European competition and we expect a tough game. We will try to break them down.

"We are playing in front of our own supporters so we want to be happy at the end of the game. We will do our best.

"I think it is a dream game. When you play football you dream about these kind of games. As a kid you watched these kind of games but now you are on the pitch playing the game.

"Everyone (in Tanzania) is talking about the game tomorrow, talking about Ally and (Virgil) Van Dijk, saying I have to do something against him, go past him, dribble.

"I think a lot of them will watch the game tomorrow."
description: Liverpool return to Champions League action on Wednesday night and trained at Melwood before flying out to Belgium
